ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Ability to work with others in writing a research paper
Learned a lot about transnational crime and its impacts on everyday people. Learned about how it occurs, why, and potential ways to stop it.
Basic economic interpretations of corruption, worked on semester long group project.

I learned so much about not only the world but how the world lacks in so many ways, and what is being done to help it. These were lessons I would not be able to receive elsewhere, and I am very grateful for Professor Palifka opening my eyes.
corruption, organized crime, and money laundering
we did a research paper for most of it
I learned a lot about current corruption practices and cases of money laundering and organized crime.
I didn't learn much.

I understood how to start a research paper from scratch, namely performing data collection, cleaning, exploration, visualization and analysis. I also learned how to structure a research paper in Economics and perform literature reviews and write bibliographies.
I learned about transnational crime and how it influences economics of countries.
Learned about corruption, organized crime, and money laundering. Strengthened by research skills through a 20 page research paper.
Got to understand the ways in which corruption and organized crime operate, and how central they are to so many aspects of modern society.
I learned about research, economics, money laundering, organized crime, and corruption.
crime, corruption

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great overview of material and the group project allows students to bring in information learned from class. No negatives.

I wish there was some other assignment than the group project in order to summarize the key concepts, because I wasn't engaged too much with the day to day class and needed some incentive to. The group project itself though went better though.

Strengths: great content, mostly great speakers

Weaknesses: I believe we started working on projects slightly early, so starting alter would be an improvement

The strength of this course is definitely the guest lectures who have interesting anecdotes. The weakness of this class is that the grade from this class is heavily dependent on the group project  and the group is chosen by the professor on the first week of class. This really makes or breaks your experience in the class for the entire semester. If you are in a group that just doesn't work well together, then not only will your grades suffer but your enjoyment of this class. In terms of the group research project, the directions and what the professor is looking for is very vague and this makes the group assignments very stressful. Aside from that, students are occasionally put into breakout rooms with our groups for the entire lecture long which is very excessive for what we are suppose to be discussing about. Usually, we'd just silently sit in  breakout room until the professor decides to pop in.

While I did enjoy the original work my group got to do for this class, there was no connection between lectures and tested material. There was no reason to attend class unless it was one of the random class periods where we spent 45 min in a breakout room working on our projects. Although the grading system was very kind in this class, the majority of points I lost for virtual presentations were based solely on the number of times I said "um" during my part. For the second of the two virtual presentations (each out of 5 points), the "individual diction" section of my rubric was labeled "unintelligible" and I was given 0/0.5 points. It's already hard enough to do a presentation over Zoom, but the fact that this professor was literally counting our "um" usage during them made it much harder.
really interesting topic, taught in a not-so interesting way. A lot of lectures and no way of retaining the information learned
This course is extremely flexible and student driven. Conversations and guest speakers were geared towards student interest.
Only take this course if you are interested in this topic. Otherwise, the course is not well-taught.

The strengths revolve around the freedom that is given in the class to explore any relevant topic in any geographical region and time period. A lot of the learning in this class was experiential and through drafting and finishing the research paper, I learned a lot about the process. The guest lectures were absolutely amazing, and gave us the opportunity to meet people fighting corruption and crime in the real world. The discussions we had were sometimes instructive and constructive. Weaknesses include the fact that there is some lack of structure to what we are learning when compared to traditional courses. It was sometimes hard to link what was being taught in lecture to what we had already covered. The writing process could however be more guided, since as of now the class has only a few checkpoints where feedback could be obtained. Prof. Palifka was however very willing to take time to give feedback upon request.
This course was great.

Could be more engaging. 
Grading was strange in the sense that extra points were given without explanation. It benefitted students a lot, so no complaints here.

I appreciated this class and I feel like the content delivery was helpful and taught me a lot about the topic. I would suggest cutting down on the number of student presentations--having fewer presentations (maybe two instead of three) may help us focus more on writing the project, and maybe leave more time for content.

Strengths: Interesting course content, engaging lectures, good feedback on assignments, professor was helpful and willing to answer questions

Weaknesses: Grading on class presentations was slightly harsh
Really enjoyed it. Learned a lot

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lecture was the most helpful.
Discussions posts worked well!
It's nice to go to breakout rooms, but there were so many class periods where we spent the majority of our time in a room.
NA

Guest lectures are great. Time alloted to the group members was useful to plan next steps in the writing process. Actual lectures were however much harder to pay attention to since some of the energy around the topics being taught get lost in the online format.
They all succeeded it was a great virtual class.
I like that it was recorded.
I enjoyed the virtual lecture format as well as the opportunity to meet with my teammates
Liked it

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: take it if you want a class that is largely self-driven by team work and a large project. Be warned the professor does take off points for the most minor errors, so polish is important in this course.
Absolutely, one of my favorite courses I've taken at Yale. Interesting material, fantastic Professor.
Yes if they are an econ major or just interested in the topic. It is a great introductory course.

Probably not, it's a gut but not a too satisfying one. The whole semester's focus is on a group project, which is great if you want to do your own research, but leaves the course without clear direction. A new guest speaker almost every week didn't help with the flow either, the course just kind of seemed pieced together.

Yes, I would, especially if you're an econ major or want to get a very unique perspective of the world. However, you would have to be okay with a main portion of your grade being determined by group work.

No. The grade from this class is heavily dependent on the group project  and the group is chosen by the professor on the first week of class. This really makes or breaks your experience in the class for the entire semester. If you are in a group that just doesn't work well together, then not only will your grades suffer but your enjoyment of this class. In terms of the group research project, the directions and what the professor is looking for is very vague and this makes the group assignments very stressful.

If you want an easy class, sure, but I thought some of the grading was unfair. Instead of grading us on our content, the professor focused on "how many ums and uhs you said" or what you were wearing during a virtual presentation. There was little to no feedback on our actual work.
Yes, not an intimidating class and covers interesting topics. Professor Palifka is fantastic.
No. Don't take it.
yes, a gut
It is definitely worth it to plunge into research paper writing and learn what it is like. Great training for a rising senior like me preparing for my thesis.
Yes I would it was taught by a great professor and had a very interesting subject.
Yes, if you're okay with group work. 75% of this class is based on your group research paper, so be wary of that.
If they are interested in the topic, yes.
I would recommend this course because it was interesting and had a professor who was willing to answer questions and provided clear feedback.
Yea, had fun

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A few in person presentations and group work outside of class.
Recorded lecture with group project.
There were also asynchronous discussions posts.
Breakout rooms during lecture
NA
none
Meetings with the professor outside class hours and group meetings with team members.
That is all.
recorded biweekly lecture
none
